descript.purpose: REQUIRED: A summary of the intentions with which the data set was developed.

citeinfo.origin: REQUIRED: The name of an organization or individual that developed the data set.

citeinfo.title: restoration_landscapes_geo

timeperd.current: REQUIRED: The basis on which the time period of content information is determined.

sngdate.caldate: REQUIRED: The year (and optionally month, or month and day) for which the data set corresponds to the ground.

status.progress: REQUIRED: The state of the data set.
status.update: REQUIRED: The frequency with which changes and additions are made to the data set after the initial data set is completed.

theme.themekt: REQUIRED: Reference to a formally registered thesaurus or a similar authoritative source of theme keywords.
theme.themekey: REQUIRED: Common-use word or phrase used to describe the subject of the data set.

idinfo.accconst: REQUIRED: Restrictions and legal prerequisites for accessing the data set.

dataIdInfo.envirDesc: Microsoft Windows 2000 Version 5.2 (Build 3790) Service Pack 2; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.1.3000
dataIdInfo.idPurp: Large areas of habitat where surveys in the past 10 years have not revealed evidence of tigers, to prioritize for restoration.
dataIdInfo.idAbs: Large areas of structural land cover under low human impact where survey efforts since 1995 have not revealed evidence of tigers. Priority restoration landscapes are the largest 20% in each bioregion. This shapefile shows restoration landscapes in the current portion of the tiger range only.
dataIdInfo.idCredit:
Dinerstein, E., Loucks, C.J., Wikramanayake, E., Ginsberg, J., Sanderson, E., Seidensticker, J., Forrest, J.L., Bryja, G., Heydlauff, A., Klenzendorf, S., Mills, J, O'Brien, T., Shrestha, M, Simons, R., Songer, M. 2007. The fate of wild tigers. BioScience 57(96):508--514
and
Wildlife Conservation Society, World Wildlife Fund, Smithsonian Institution, Save the Tiger Fund (WCS, WWF, Smithsonian, STF). 2006. Setting Priorities for Conservation and Recovery of Wild Tigers 2005-2010. Funded by Save the Tiger Fund, the Critical Ecosystem Partnership Fund, the United Nations Foundation, and the Zoological Society of London. July 2006. Internet web site: http://www.tigermaps.org
